awd_titl_txt: 2021 FRONTIERS OF ENGINEERING SYMPOSIA (US FOE AND GERMAN-AMERICAN FOE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide emerging engineering leaders from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share research insights to facilitate an interdisciplinary transfer of knowledge and research methodologies. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic growth makes it essential that engineers understand research developments, techniques and approaches beyond their own discipline. The symposia serve as a catalyst to spur engineering innovation and foster collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and between engineers from the United States and partnering countries. The FOE symposia may also serve to increase the visibility of engineering and to highlight the key roles through which engineers serve society.

This award will provide partial support for two Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) symposia, to be held in 2021. These symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) in concert with international partner organizations, are for early career researchers. The meetings to be funded by this award in 2021 are: German-American FOE (March, 2021; Oak Ridge, Tennessee); and US FOE (September, 2021; Boulder, Colorado). The 2021 GAFOE will focus on Quantum Computing, Carbon Capture and Utilization, Manufacturing 4.0, and Biologization (defined as the creation of machines from biological units). Topics for the 2021 US FOE symposium are: Building Resilience to Pandemics, Cybersecurity of Infrastructure, Direct Air Capture for Climate Mitigation, and Engineering the Future of Space Exploration. Approximately 100 outstanding young engineers for the U.S. symposium and 30 from each country for the bilateral symposium will participate. Each two and a half day symposium will include plenary sessions, break-out and poster sessions, and opportunities for developing collaborative research partnerships. Sessions will consist of presentations on cutting-edge research, innovations, and emerging research opportunities in engineering fields relevant to the symposium. As the scheduled dates for each symposium approaches, pandemic status assessments will be conducted to determine whether to delay the meeting or convert to a virtual format. If meetings are held virtually, the online platform will be purposely designed to afford robust networking opportunities. FOE symposium papers, abstracts, presentation videos, and slides will be made available on the FOE website (www.naefrontiers.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering, provide highly accomplished early-career engineers from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share their research and technical work, which facilitates interdisciplinary exchange across diverse engineering fields. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic grown in an increasingly competitive environment have heightened the need for engineers to understand each other's disciplines. The  symposia are a catalyst for innovation that fosters collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and across national boundaries. This award provided partial support for the 2021 German-American FOE held March 17-19 as a virtual event and the US FOE held September 22-24 as a hybrid event in Irvine, California. Presentations and discussion focused on topics that included among others: quantum computing, carbon capture and utilization, manufacturing 4.0, the future of space exploration, resilience in pandemics, and cybersecurity of critical infrastructure. The virtual and hybrid meetings included informal networking time, poster sessions, and breakout groups. Presentation abstracts, videos or slides, and posters are available on the meeting websites at www.naefrontiers.org.

The following results and comments were obtained from surveys of meeting attendees:

German-American FOE (Virtual)
Virtual meeting structure: good or excellent 95%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent 98%
Ability to interact virtually during networking times: good or excellent 93%
Range of topics: about right 95%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//informal discussion in other disciplines: Yes or possibly 92%//84%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: 87%//83%
Usefulness to professional development: useful or very useful 97%

Comments:

I teach a lot so this material is going to feed into courses!

I feel better versed on topics that are out of my field. Also, I have met several folks that I'd like to keep communicating with.

I particularly enjoyed the Grand Challenges discussion! In addition, the broad range of topics made this conference really stand out compared to others I've attended.

Through networking with people tangential to my field, I learned a lot and felt like I could contribute something from my own expertise that was new or at least something less familiar to others. This is ideal for starting new collaborations. In that way, it was far superior to attending a meeting specific to my subfield.

Besides the exchange with colleagues from my field (quantum computing), the discussion with chemical engineers was super interesting as we could find out what kind of (quantum) simulations might be useful for them. I like the random shuffling during the informal discussions. This is definitely an advantage compared to in-person meetings where people tend to stay together in fixed groups.

US FOE (Hybrid)

Meeting format: good or excellent 93%
Quality of presentations: good or excellent 97%
Opportunity to participate: good or excellent  91%
Choice of topics: good or excellent 95%
Gained something useful to work/research from presentations//discussion in other disciplines: yes or possibly 93%//89%
Identified potential collaborative opportunities//applications of interdisciplinary approaches: yes or possibly 91%//97%
Usefulness to professional development: useful or very useful 96%

Comments:

There are a few researchers I want to follow up with to discuss optimization methods and 3D fabrication methods for potential collaborations. 

Fundamentally, the meeting was inspiring. The other attendees, presenters, and committee members were so curious, engaging, and articulate that I have returned home with more vigor than before the trip. Specifically, there were many new technology touchpoints in other industries such as space, hydrogen technologies, DAC, and the refinery industry. I hope to leverage these connections and abilities for some time to come. 

I see the symposium as being very influential in my early career as it gave me the opportunity to meet colleagues working in fields related to my own but also very disparate fields. I suspect the connections made and ideas shared will lead to new research paths and collaborative efforts. 

It gave me the opportunity to see first hand the benefit of interdisciplinary fields in advancing frontiers of engineering in other domains. In other words, I learned how engineering concepts from biomedical engineering were being used in manufacturing of vegan food to get the texture right. It was fascinating. I could also see similarities between what I do and a peer at Purdue was doing in the field of sustainable manufacturing. 

GRAINGER GRANTS


Two grants of $30,000 from The Grainger Foundation were awarded to US FOE attendees who developed collaborative research projects. The recipients were: 

Jamel Ali (Florida A&M University and Florida State University College of Engineering) and Kaitlyn Sadtler (National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering) for "Evaluating the role of micro-mechanical remodeling during immune-mediating tissue regeneration"

Xiaowei Yue (Virginia Tech) and Marco Salviato (University of Washington) for "Novel physics-informed machine learning framework for quality control for composite structures assembly"

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/21/2022
Modified by: Janet R Hunziker
